semantic_title: Use of Symptom Code with Definitive Diagnosis Code
section_path: Section I > C. Chapter-Specific Coding Guidelines > 18. Chapter 18: Symptoms, signs, and abnormal clinical and laboratory findings, not elsewhere classified (R00-R99) > b. Use of a symptom code with a definitive diagnosis code

content.full_text: Codes for signs and symptoms may be reported in addition to a related definitive diagnosis when the sign or symptom is not routinely associated with that diagnosis, such as the various signs and symptoms associated with complex syndromes. The definitive diagnosis code should be sequenced before the symptom code. Signs or symptoms that are associated routinely with a disease process should not be assigned as additional codes, unless otherwise instructed by the classification. (Evidence: pg no: 75, L86-L88)
content.summary: Symptom codes can be used with definitive diagnosis codes when symptoms are not routinely associated with the diagnosis, with definitive diagnosis sequenced first, but routine symptoms should not be coded separately (Evidence: pg no: 75, L86-L88)

detailed_rules.rule_text: Code symptoms in addition to definitive diagnosis when symptom is not routinely associated with the diagnosis (Evidence: pg no: 75, L86-L87)
detailed_rules.explanation: When a patient has symptoms that are not typically expected or routinely seen with their diagnosed condition, these symptoms should be coded separately (Evidence: pg no: 75, L86-L87)

detailed_rules.rule_text: Definitive diagnosis code should be sequenced before symptom code (Evidence: pg no: 75, L87)
detailed_rules.explanation: When both definitive diagnosis and symptom codes are assigned, the definitive diagnosis takes precedence in sequencing (Evidence: pg no: 75, L87)
common_applications: All encounters with both definitive diagnosis and non-routine symptoms

detailed_rules.rule_text: Do not assign additional codes for symptoms routinely associated with a disease process (Evidence: pg no: 75, L88)
detailed_rules.explanation: Symptoms that are expected and routinely occur with a particular diagnosis should not be coded separately unless specifically instructed by the classification (Evidence: pg no: 75, L88)

workflow_steps: Step 3: Determine which symptoms are routinely associated with diagnosis
